Award.AwardTitle: 28th Annual Pacific Northwest Numerical Analysis Seminar 2015 at Western Washington University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the 28th Pacific Northwest Numerical Analysis Seminar (PNWNAS), held at Western Washington University, October 17, 2015. As an annual event for the past twenty-seven years, PNWNAS has become one of the primary means for local research groups in numerical computation to engage in scientific exchanges. With invited speakers from industry, government, and academia, PNWNAS 2015 will help keep its participants abreast of recent developments in the field of computational mathematics and numerical analysis, hence fostering research interactions and further promoting mathematical innovation regionally as well as globally. One of the invited lectures will be a designated public presentation accessible to a broader audience on a subject of public interest, such as modeling in the social sciences. This will benefit both the scientific community and the general public in Bellingham. This award will encourage and support the involvement of traditionally underrepresented groups by providing some exclusive financial support for them.

A broad range of interdisciplinary research topics will be covered, including mathematical modeling and numerical simulation of large-scale complex systems in applied fields, such as biology, chemical engineering, fluid mechanics, medical science, and materials science. Topics will also include numerical linear algebra, multi-scale modeling and simulation, stochastic processes, inverse problems, and image processing. Poster sessions presented mainly by graduate students and postdoctoral fellows will provide early-stage researchers with an opportunity to showcase their academic achievements. The goals of PNWNAS 2015 include: to foster the scientific interaction of computational mathematics groups from academia, industry, and government agencies working in a broad range of science and technology; to promote mathematical innovation regionally as well as globally; to facilitate interactions that potentially lead to regional employment and internship opportunities for postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduates; and to attract prospective students into the Pacific Northwest's higher education programs in computational and applied mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report of the 28th Annual Pacific Northwest Numerical Analysis Seminar

0. Summary

The 28th Annual Pacific Northwest Numerical Analysis Seminar (PNWNAS) was held at WWU on October 17, 2015. Around 55 registered scientists and more than 10 on-site participants, from over 14 universities and 4 companies, attended. The program began with a welcome remark by Tjalling Ypma, followed by a series of eight invited presentations, with talk videos available on the conference website.  Poster sessions were also held in the middle of both morning and afternoon during coffee breaks. The talks showcased the interaction of computational mathematics with a broad range of science and technology including biological modeling, bio-fluid dynamics of locomotion, stochastic and deterministic climate modeling, scripted geometry processing for manufacturing, as well as simulation of blast-induced blood-brain barrier disruption. All in all, the conference was a great success.

1. Background

PNWNAS is a recurring conference series (http://faculty.washington.edu/rjl/pnwnas/), annually held in a northwestern state of the United States (Alaska, Idaho, Oregon or Washington) or the neighboring Canadian province, British Columbia. It brings in computational experts and numerical analysts from various scientific and engineering disciplines of academia, government and industry scattered across the Pacific Northwest. PNWNAS has been an annual event since 1987, held on a Saturday each fall.

This was the fifth time for the Department of Mathematics at WWU to host PNWNAS, which definitely provided an excellent opportunity for both our faculty and students to further explore practical and timely research topics in numerical analysis and computational mathematics. Especially for many of our students, this was a brand new experience to explore cutting-edge research in the world of computational science.

The financial support from NSF enabled PNWNAS 2015 organizers to invite a variety of high quality speakers and increase the participation, especially student participation, in the seminar’s activities. The exposure to topics and techniques not typically available at the home universities and the opportunity for face-to-face collaboration enhanced the research programs of faculty, student and Postdoc participants. 

 2. Delegates

The conference was attended by 70 delegates (55 registered) representing 18 institutions. In addition to participants from academia and government labs, we welcomed computational scientists from 4 companies. All the participants are from the field of computational mathematics. The distribution is as follows:

British Columbia, Canada: 7

Georgia, USA: 1

Idaho, USA: 1

Louisiana, USA: 2

New York, USA: 1

Oregon, USA: 6

Washington, USA: 36

 

Professors: 30

Postdoctoral Fellows: 5

Graduate Students: 15

Industrial Scientists: 5  

 

Males: 44

Females: 11

3. Program

The seminar was held in SMATE Building, Room 110 on WWU campus, with the following programs:

08:00-09:00     Registration

09:00-09:45     Robert Dillon (Washington State University): Mathematical modeling of sperm and cilia motility 

09:45-10:30     Lisa Fauci (Tulane University): Explorations in the biofluiddynamics of locomotion

10:30  -  11:00     Break and Poster Session

11:00  -  11:45     Michele Benzi (Emory University): Numerical methods for solving PDEs on graphs   

11:45  -  12:30     Bhoualem Khouider (University of Victoria): Stochastic and deterministic multi-cloud models for tropical climate dynamics

12:30  -  02:00     Lunch Break

02:00  -   02:45     Eldad Haber (University of British Columbia): On large scale inverse problems that cannot be solved  

02:45  -   03:30     Nathan Gibson (Oregon State University): A polynomial chaos method for dispersive electromagnetics  

03:30  -   04:00     Break and Poster Session

04:00  -   04:45     Thomas A. Grandine (The Boeing Company): Scripted geometry processing for manufacturing 

04:45  -   05:30     Mauricio Del Razo Sarmina (University of Washington): Computational and in vitro studies of blast-induced blood-brain barrier disruption   

4. Poster Presentations

 Vrushali A. Bokil, Puttha Sakkaplangkul (Oregon State University): A Weighted Sequential Splitting Method for the 3D Maxwell’s Equations

V. Gyrya, G. Manzini, D. A. McGregor (Oregon State University): An Arbitrary Order Mimetic Finite Difference Method for the 3D DeRham Complex

Francois Monard (University of Michigan), Donsub Rim (University of Washington): Inverse Diffusion From Knowledge of Power Densities in Dimension 3

Bin Jiang, Timothy Meagher (Portland State University),  Peng Jiang (University of Florida): Numerical Simulation of Antireflection Coatings on Glass

Evan Johnson, Brandon Peden (Western Washington University),  Seth Rittenhouse (United States Naval Academy and Western Washington University): Modeling Particle Transport in 1D Atomic Lattices with Overlap Impurities

Alex Townsend, Grady Wright, Heather Wilber (Boise State University): Low Rank Function Approximation on the Sphere and Disk 

 5. Scientific Benefits

  • To foster the interaction of computational mathematics with a broad range of science and technology.
  • To build new interdisciplinary research communities and to promote mathematical innovation regionally as well as globally.
  • To facilitate interactions which potentially lead to regional employment and internship opportunities for postdoctoral fellows, graduate and undergraduate students.
  • To attract prospective students into the Pacific Northwest’s higher education programs in computational and applied mathematics.
  • To strongly promote, encourage and support the careers of women and underrepresented ethnic groups in the Pacific Northwest.

6. Conference Website

 https://sites.google.com/site/pnwnas2015/


Last Modified: 10/30/2016
Modified by: Jianying Zhang
